text: And when she had done giving him drink, she said, I will draw water for thy camels also, until they have done drinking.
text_kjv: And when she had done giving him drink, she said, I will draw water for thy camels also, until they have done drinking.
text_niv: After she had given him a drink, she said, “I’ll draw water for your camels too, until they have finished drinking.”
text_esv: When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, “I will draw water for your camels also, until they have finished drinking.”
text_nlt: When she had given him a drink, she said, “I’ll draw water for your camels, too, until they have had enough to drink.”
text_msg: When he had satisfied his thirst she said, "I'll get water for your camels, too, until they've drunk their fill."
text_nasb: Now when she had finished giving him a drink, she said, 'I will draw also for your camels until they have finished drinking.'
context: Genesis 24:19 occurs within a pivotal narrative concerning Abraham's desire to find a suitable wife for his son Isaac. Abraham, deeply concerned about preserving the lineage and faith of his family, sends his most trusted servant, likely Eliezer of Damascus, on a mission to his ancestral homeland in Mesopotamia. This region, specifically the city of Nahor, represented the connection to Abraham's extended family and the culture that preceded his covenant with God. The servant is tasked with finding a woman from Abraham's relatives who would be willing to leave her home and family to marry Isaac and continue the Abrahamic line. Water was an extremely precious and laboriously obtained resource in the ancient Near East. Wells were often communal gathering places, especially for women, who were responsible for drawing and carrying water for their families and livestock. Drawing water from a well was physically demanding work, involving lowering a heavy bucket and then hauling it up, often repeatedly. Camels, in particular, could drink an enormous amount of water, especially after a long journey. A single camel could consume 20-30 gallons. Therefore, offering to water a whole caravan of camels represented a significant act of extraordinary hospitality and generosity. It demonstrated not only physical strength and willingness to work hard but also an uncommon level of kindness and consideration for both the servant and his animals. Social customs dictated that hospitality was a sacred duty, especially towards travelers. Refusal to offer water and shelter was considered a grave offense. This story underscores the importance of lineage, divine providence, and the cultural expectations surrounding marriage and hospitality in ancient Mesopotamian society. The servant's elaborate test to identify the suitable bride highlights the significance of the decision and the desire for divine guidance in this matter.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 24:19 highlights several important themes. Firstly, it showcases the providence of God. Eliezer prays for a sign – that the woman chosen by God will offer him water and also volunteer to water his camels. Rebekah fulfills this specific request, demonstrating God's active involvement in guiding Eliezer to the right person. Her actions are not merely a coincidence but a divinely orchestrated event pointing towards her suitability as Isaac’s wife. Secondly, Rebekah's act of extraordinary service reflects the characteristics that God values. Her willingness to go above and beyond what was expected, offering water not only to Eliezer but also to his thirsty camels, embodies selflessness, compassion, and a servant heart. These qualities foreshadow the kind of person who would be a suitable partner for Isaac and a worthy matriarch for the nation of Israel. Thirdly, the narrative symbolizes the overflowing grace of God. Just as Rebekah offered water in abundance, God provides abundantly for those who seek Him. Her willingness to meet a need, both physical and spiritual, mirrors God’s own boundless provision and love. The sheer quantity of water needed to quench the thirst of a whole caravan speaks to the immeasurable nature of God’s gifts. Furthermore, Rebekah's story foreshadows the role of the church as a servant to the world, offering spiritual refreshment and sustenance to those in need. Her example challenges us to extend hospitality and generosity to strangers, recognizing them as potential recipients of God's grace and blessings. The narrative emphasizes that true faith is expressed not only in words but also in acts of service and compassion. Her active demonstration of kindness validates her selection as a pivotal figure in the lineage of Christ.
application: In our modern world, Genesis 24:19 provides a powerful example of practical Christian living. Rebekah's actions challenge us to examine our own attitudes towards service and hospitality. Do we readily offer help to those in need, even when it requires significant effort and inconvenience? Her willingness to draw water for a large group of camels, a task that would have been physically demanding and time-consuming, teaches us the importance of selfless service. We can apply this principle by actively seeking opportunities to serve others in our communities, our churches, and even in our daily interactions. This might involve volunteering at a local soup kitchen, offering a helping hand to a neighbor, or simply showing kindness to a stranger. The verse also encourages us to be attentive to the needs of others, both physical and spiritual. Just as Rebekah recognized Eliezer's thirst, we should be observant and compassionate, looking for ways to meet the needs of those around us. This could involve offering practical assistance, providing emotional support, or sharing the gospel with those who are seeking truth. Furthermore, Rebekah's example reminds us that hospitality is not merely about entertaining guests but about extending genuine care and kindness to those who may be different from us or less fortunate. In a world that is often divided by prejudice and suspicion, we are called to emulate Rebekah's generous spirit by welcoming strangers, showing compassion to those in need, and breaking down barriers of division. We can also learn from Eliezer's reliance on prayer. He specifically requested a sign from God, and God answered his prayer through Rebekah's actions. This reminds us of the importance of seeking God's guidance in our decisions and trusting in His providence. We should regularly pray for opportunities to serve others and ask God to lead us to those who need our help. Finally, Rebekah's story encourages us to be willing to go above and beyond in our service to others. It's not enough to simply meet the minimum requirements; we should strive to exceed expectations, offering our time, talents, and resources generously and cheerfully.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the inspiring example of Rebekah's selfless service. Help me to cultivate a heart of compassion and a willingness to serve others, even when it is inconvenient or challenging. Give me the strength and energy to go above and beyond in meeting the needs of those around me. Lord, open my eyes to the opportunities You place before me each day to show kindness and generosity. Help me to be more attentive to the needs of others, both physical and spiritual. Fill me with Your Spirit, that I may reflect Your love and grace in all that I do. Guide me in my decisions and lead me to those who need my help. I pray that my actions may glorify You and draw others closer to Your saving grace. In Jesus' name, Amen.
